column4: hi. I need help with xorg.conf. I chose to enable the nvidia driver and now it's not recognizing my monitor. Before I have been told to delete xorg.conf when this happens and it worked. This time I deleted it and now things are worse. Nothing loads.
do you have console access?
I had a blinking cursor, but I couldn't type anything. Right now I'm using the install disk live to talk in here.
ah, your best bet is to chroot then and run nvidia-xconfig
actually... you probably dont even need to chroot.. install the nvidia drivers via the livecd, run nvidia-xconfig and then copy the xorg.conf it creates to your root partition after mounting it
Ok. I'm gonna try it.
you know how to do all that?
I'm not so good with the command line. I might be able to just use synaptic to get the driver installed.
yeah, thats the easy part ;)
which version of nvidia should I install. when things got messed up earlier I had installed nvidia-current.
can you mount your root partition?
I ran nautilus in root to get to the xorg.conf. that's how I deleted it.
if you have an xorg.conf in /etc/X11 on your root partition you can change Driver "nvidia" to Driver "nv" and X will probably work
and codebrainz: I did the reconfigure in the terminal. I now have a new xorg.conf and the driver says "vesa"
so you know how to mount your root partition?
I guess. I just used sudo nautilus and went from there.
ok, so you have no problem taking the xorg.conf from the livecd and putting it in your root etc/X11/ then?
edit the file and change vesa to nv
I will try nv instead of vesa
good luck!!  should work no problem
thanks
you are using the nv driver which is the open source driver, not the nvidia binary driver
I am willing to guess that the nvidia driver isnt recognizing the EDID of your monitor and X isnt starting properly
yes. it has recognized it before, but I have installed lucid lynx  and now it doesn't
